sections.appendix d applications in document span:
This section presents an application of our enumeration algorithm to the evaluation of recursive spannersÂ . Practical formalisms to define document spanner for information extraction with recursion was only proposed very recently. InÂ [ref]49, the author suggests using extraction grammars to specify document spanners, which is the natural extension of regular spanners to a controlled form of recursion. Furthermore, the author gives an enumeration algorithm for unambiguous functional extraction grammars that outputs the results with constant-delay after quintic time preprocessing (i.e., in the document). We can show a streaming enumeration algorithm with update-time that is independent of the document, and output-linear delay by restricting to the class of visibly pushdown extraction grammars. We proceed by recalling the framework of document spanners and extraction grammars to define the class of visibly pushdown extraction grammars and state the main algorithmic result. We start by recalling the basics of document spannersÂ . Fix an alphabetÂ Î£Î£\Sigma and a set of variables ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œ\mathsf{Vars} such that Î£âˆ©ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œ=âˆ…Î£ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œ\Sigma\cap\mathsf{Vars}=\emptyset. A document dğ‘‘d over Î£Î£\Sigma is basically a word in Î£âˆ—superscriptÎ£\Sigma^{*}. A span sğ‘ s of a document dğ‘‘d is a pair [i,jâŸ©ğ‘–ğ‘—[i,j\rangle of natural numbers iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j with 1â‰¤iâ‰¤jâ‰¤|d|+11ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘‘11\leq i\leq j\leq|d|+1. Intuitively, a span represents a substring of dğ‘‘d by identifying the starting and ending position.
We denote by ğ–²ğ—‰ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—Œâ€‹(d)ğ–²ğ—‰ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—Œğ‘‘\mathsf{Spans}(d) the set of all possible spans of dğ‘‘d.
Let XâŠ†ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œğ‘‹ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—ŒX\subseteq\mathsf{Vars} be a finite set of variables.
An (X,d)ğ‘‹ğ‘‘(X,d)-mapping Î¼:Xâ†’ğ–²ğ—‰ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—Œâ€‹(d):ğœ‡â†’ğ‘‹ğ–²ğ—‰ğ–ºğ—‡ğ—Œğ‘‘\mu\colon X\rightarrow\mathsf{Spans}(d) assigns variables in Xğ‘‹X to spans of dğ‘‘d. An (X,d)ğ‘‹ğ‘‘(X,d)-relation is a finite set of (X,d)ğ‘‹ğ‘‘(X,d)-mappings. Then a document spanner Pğ‘ƒP (or just spanner) is a function associated with a finite set Xğ‘‹X of variables that maps documents dğ‘‘d into (X,d)ğ‘‹ğ‘‘(X,d)-relations. We use the framework of extraction grammars, recently proposed inÂ [ref]49, to specify document spanners.
For XâŠ†ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œğ‘‹ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—ŒX\subseteq\mathsf{Vars}, let CX={{x,}xâˆ£xâˆˆX}\pazocal{C}_{X}=\{\{_{x},\}_{x}\mid x\in X\} be the set of captures of Xğ‘‹X where, intuitively, {x\{_{x} denotes the opening of xğ‘¥x, and }x\}_{x} its closing.
An extraction context-free grammar, or extraction grammar for short, is a tuple G=(X,V,Î£,S,P)ğºğ‘‹ğ‘‰Î£ğ‘†ğ‘ƒG=(X,V,\Sigma,S,P) such that XâŠ†ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œğ‘‹ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—ŒX\subseteq\mathsf{Vars}, Vğ‘‰V is a finite set of non-terminals symbols with Vâˆ©ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œ=âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—ŒV\cap\mathsf{Vars}=\emptyset, Î£Î£\Sigma is the alphabet of terminal symbols with Î£âˆ©V=âˆ…Î£ğ‘‰\Sigma\cap V=\emptyset, SâˆˆVğ‘†ğ‘‰S\in V is the start symbol, and PâŠ†VÃ—(VâˆªÎ£âˆªCX)âˆ—ğ‘ƒğ‘‰superscriptğ‘‰Î£subscriptCXP\subseteq V\times(V\cup\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*} is a finite relation. In the literature, the elements of Vğ‘‰V are also referred as â€œvariablesâ€, but we call them non-terminals to distinguish Vğ‘‰V fromÂ ğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œğ–µğ–ºğ—‹ğ—Œ\mathsf{Vars}.
Each pair (A,Î±)âˆˆPğ´ğ›¼ğ‘ƒ(A,\alpha)\in P is called a production and we write it as Aâ†’Î±â†’ğ´ğ›¼A\rightarrow\alpha. The set of productions Pğ‘ƒP defines the (left) derivation relation â‡’GâŠ†(VâˆªÎ£âˆªCX)âˆ—Ã—(VâˆªÎ£âˆªCX)âˆ—\Rightarrow_{G}\ \subseteq\,(V\cup\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*}\times(V\cup\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*} such that wâ€‹Aâ€‹Î²â‡’Gwâ€‹Î±â€‹Î²subscriptâ‡’ğºğ‘¤ğ´ğ›½ğ‘¤ğ›¼ğ›½wA\beta\Rightarrow_{G}w\alpha\beta iff wâˆˆ(Î£âˆªCX)âˆ—ğ‘¤superscriptÎ£subscriptCXw\in(\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*}, AâˆˆVğ´ğ‘‰A\in V, Î±,Î²âˆˆ(VâˆªÎ£âˆªCX)âˆ—ğ›¼ğ›½superscriptğ‘‰Î£subscriptCX\alpha,\beta\in(V\cup\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*}, and Aâ†’Î±âˆˆPâ†’ğ´ğ›¼ğ‘ƒA\rightarrow\alpha\in P. We denote by â‡’Gâˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ‡’ğº\Rightarrow_{G}^{*} the reflexive and transitive closure of â‡’Gsubscriptâ‡’ğº\Rightarrow_{G}. Then the language defined by GğºG is Lâ€‹(G)={wâˆˆ(Î£âˆªCX)âˆ—âˆ£Sâ‡’Gâˆ—w}LGconditional-setwsuperscriptÎ£subscriptCXsuperscriptsubscriptâ‡’GSw\pazocal{L}(G)=\{w\in(\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*}\mid S\Rightarrow_{G}^{*}w\}.
A word wâˆˆLâ€‹(G)ğ‘¤LGw\in\pazocal{L}(G) is called a ref-word produced by GğºG. In order to define a spanner from GğºG, we need to interpret ref-words as mappingsÂ 9. Formally, a ref-word r=a1â€‹â€¦â€‹anâˆˆ(Î£âˆªCX)âˆ—ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›superscriptÎ£subscriptCXr=a_{1}\ldots a_{n}\in(\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*} is called valid for Xğ‘‹X if, for every xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X, there exists exactly one position iğ‘–i with ai={xa_{i}=\{_{x} and exactly one position jğ‘—j with aj=}xa_{j}=\ \}_{x}, such that i<jğ‘–ğ‘—i<j. In other words, a valid ref-word defines a correct match of open and close captures. Moreover, each xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X induces a unique factorization of rğ‘Ÿr of the form r=rxpâ‹…{xâ‹…rxâ‹…}xâ‹…rxsr=r_{x}^{p}\cdot\{_{x}\,\cdot\,r_{x}\,\cdot\,\}_{x}\cdot r_{x}^{s}.
This factorization defines an (X,d)ğ‘‹ğ‘‘(X,d)-mapping as follows.
Let plain:(Î£âˆªCX)âˆ—â†’Î£âˆ—:plainâ†’superscriptÎ£subscriptCXsuperscriptÎ£\textsf{plain}:(\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*}\rightarrow\Sigma^{*} be the morphism that removes the captures from ref-words, namely, plainâ€‹(a)=aplainğ‘ğ‘\textsf{plain}(a)=a when aâˆˆÎ£ğ‘Î£a\in\Sigma and plainâ€‹(c)=Îµplainğ‘ğœ€\textsf{plain}(c)=\varepsilon when câˆˆCXğ‘subscriptCXc\in\pazocal{C}_{X}.
We extend plain to operate over strings in the obvious way.
Furthermore, let rğ‘Ÿr be a valid ref-word for Xğ‘‹X, dğ‘‘d be a document, and assume that plainâ€‹(r)=dplainğ‘Ÿğ‘‘\textsf{plain}(r)=d.
Then we define the (X,d)ğ‘‹ğ‘‘(X,d)-mapping Î¼rsuperscriptğœ‡ğ‘Ÿ\mu^{r} such that Î¼râ€‹(x)=[i,jâŸ©superscriptğœ‡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—\mu^{r}(x)=[i,j\rangle iff r=rxpâ‹…{xâ‹…rxâ‹…}xâ‹…rxsr=r_{x}^{p}\cdot\{_{x}\,\cdot\,r_{x}\,\cdot\,\}_{x}\cdot r_{x}^{s}, i=|plainâ€‹(rxp)|+1ğ‘–plainsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¥ğ‘1i=|\textsf{plain}(r_{x}^{p})|+1, and j=i+|plainâ€‹(rx)|ğ‘—ğ‘–plainsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¥j=i+|\textsf{plain}(r_{x})|.
Finally, the spanner âŸ¦GâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğº\llbracket G\mkern 1.0mu\rrbracket associated to an extraction grammar GğºG is defined over any document dâˆˆÎ£âˆ—ğ‘‘superscriptÎ£d\in\Sigma^{*} as follows: There are two classes of extraction grammars that are relevant for our discussion.
The first class of grammars are called functional extraction grammars.
An extraction grammar GğºG is functional if every râˆˆLâ€‹(G)ğ‘ŸLGr\in\pazocal{L}(G) is valid for Xğ‘‹X. InÂ [ref]49 it was shown that for any extraction grammar GğºG there exists an equivalent functional grammar Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime} (i.e. âŸ¦GâŸ§=âŸ¦Gâ€²âŸ§\llbracket G\mkern 1.0mu\rrbracket=\llbracket G^{\prime}\mkern 1.0mu\rrbracket). Non-functional grammars are problematic given that, even for regular spanners, their decision problems easily become intractableÂ  . For this reason, we restrict to functional extraction grammars without loss of expressive power.
The second class of grammars are called unambiguous extraction grammars. An extraction grammar GğºG is unambiguous if for every râˆˆLâ€‹(G)ğ‘ŸLGr\in\pazocal{L}(G) there exists exactly one path from Sğ‘†S to rğ‘Ÿr in the graph ((VâˆªÎ£âˆªCX)âˆ—,â‡’G)superscriptğ‘‰Î£subscriptCXsubscriptâ‡’G((V\cup\Sigma\cup\pazocal{C}_{X})^{*},\Rightarrow_{G}). In other words, there exists exactly one left-most derivation. We consider now a sub-class of extraction grammars for nested words. Let Î£=(Î£<,Î£>,Î£|)Î£superscriptÎ£<superscriptÎ£>superscriptÎ£|\Sigma=(\Sigma^{\texttt{<}},\Sigma^{\texttt{>}},\Sigma^{\texttt{|}}) be a structured alphabet. Then a visibly pushdown extraction grammar (VPEG) is a functional extraction grammar G=(X,V,Î£,S,P)ğºğ‘‹ğ‘‰Î£ğ‘†ğ‘ƒG=(X,V,\Sigma,S,P) in which Î£=(Î£<,Î£>,Î£|)Î£superscriptÎ£<superscriptÎ£>superscriptÎ£|\Sigma=(\Sigma^{\texttt{<}},\Sigma^{\texttt{>}},\Sigma^{\texttt{|}}) is a structured alphabet, and all the productions in Pğ‘ƒP are of one of the following forms: (1) Aâ†’Îµâ†’ğ´ğœ€A\rightarrow\varepsilon; (2) Aâ†’aâ€‹Bâ†’ğ´ğ‘ğµA\rightarrow aB such that aâˆˆÎ£|âˆªCXğ‘superscriptÎ£|subscriptCXa\in\Sigma^{\texttt{|}}\cup\pazocal{C}_{X} and BâˆˆVğµğ‘‰B\in V; (3) Aâ†’<â€‹aâ€‹Bâ€‹bâ€‹>â€‹Câ†’ğ´<ğ‘ğµğ‘>ğ¶A\rightarrow{\scriptsize\texttt{<}}a\,B\,b{\scriptsize\texttt{>}}\,C such that <â€‹aâˆˆÎ£<<ğ‘superscriptÎ£<{\scriptsize\texttt{<}}a\in\Sigma^{\texttt{<}}, bâ€‹>âˆˆÎ£>ğ‘>superscriptÎ£>b{\scriptsize\texttt{>}}\in\Sigma^{\texttt{>}}, and B,CâˆˆVğµğ¶ğ‘‰B,C\in V. Intuitively, rules Aâ†’aâ€‹Bâ†’ğ´ğ‘ğµA\rightarrow aB allow to produce arbitrary sequences of neutral symbols, where rules Aâ†’<â€‹aâ€‹Bâ€‹bâ€‹>â€‹Câ†’ğ´<ğ‘ğµğ‘>ğ¶A\rightarrow{\scriptsize\texttt{<}}a\,B\,b{\scriptsize\texttt{>}}\,C forces the word to be well-nested. Visibly pushdown extraction grammars are a subclass of extraction grammars that works for well-nested documents. In fact, the reader can notice that the visibly pushdown restriction for extraction grammars is the analog counterpart of visibly pushdown grammars111The definition of visibly pushdown grammars inÂ  is slightly more complicated given that they consider nested words that are not necessary well-nested (see the discussion in SectionÂ 2). introduced inÂ . Therefore, one could expect that VPEGs are less expressive than extraction grammars.
Interestingly, we can use TheoremÂ 4.3 to give an efficient streaming enumeration algorithm for evaluating VPEG. Fix a set of variables Xğ‘‹X. The problem of, given a visibly pushdown extraction grammar G=(X,V,Î£,S,P)ğºğ‘‹ğ‘‰Î£ğ‘†ğ‘ƒG=(X,V,\Sigma,S,P) and a stream SS\pazocal{S}, enumerating all (X,Sâ€‹[1,n])ğ‘‹S1n(X,\pazocal{S}[1,n])-mappings of âŸ¦GâŸ§(w)\llbracket G\mkern 1.0mu\rrbracket(w) can be solved with update-time Oâ€‹(2|G|3)Osuperscript2superscriptG3\pazocal{O}(2^{|G|^{3}}), and output-linear delay. Furthermore, if GğºG is restricted to be unambiguous, then the problem can be solved with update-time Oâ€‹(|G|3)OsuperscriptG3\pazocal{O}(|G|^{3}). This result goes by constructing an extraction pushdown automataÂ [ref]49 from GğºG, and reduce it to a visibly pushdown transducers. Note that, although the update-time of the algorithm is exponential in the size of the grammar, in terms of data-complexity the update-time is constant. Furthermore, for the special case of unambiguous grammars the update-time is even polynomial. Unambiguous grammars are very common in parsing tasksÂ  and, thus, this restriction could be useful in practice.
